comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8) Gecko/20051111 Firefox/1.5

All the js function I use in my HTML pages to produce simple dynamic form elements (such as empty select options or hidden fields) fail throwing the following exception:

Error: uncaught exception: [Exception... "String contains an invalid character"  code: "5" nsresult: "0x80530005 (NS_ERROR_DOM_INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR)"

Some code examples are:
document.createElement('<input type="hidden"/>')
document.createElement("<option selected></option>")

It all worked up to FireFox 1.0.7...
and I found no DOM indication about avoiding this type of operations.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a page with a javascript function like this:
<script>
function foo() {
  var newRadioButton = document.createElement("<INPUT TYPE='RADIO' NAME='RADIOTEST' VALUE='First Choice'>")
  document.body.insertBefore(newRadioButton);
}
</script>

<input type="button" onclick="foo()" value="Click to throw exception">
2. Look at the Javascript console
3. Click the button

Actual Results:  
NS_ERROR_DOM_INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR

Expected Results:  
The creation of the button control

comments.author: sync2d@gmail.com
comments.text:
createElement() requires the name of the element
type to instantiate, but not HTML/XML fragment.
http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-2-Core/core.html#ID-2141741547

While this is an old bug, and resolved Invalid, I have just noticed the same problem with Firefox 3.0a5pre (Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9a5) Gecko/20070606 GranParadiso/3.0a5)
and with Seamonkey 1.1.2 (Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1.4) Gecko/20070509 SeaMonkey/1.1.2)

What bothers me is that IE v6 doesn't show this error when running the same Javascript code.

The code can be found at http://www.cdgo.govt.nz/Javascript/Global.js
The error occurs on line 61
